Issues.Title: Add a SortBy pipe/function akin to AngularJs' one
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Description
In AngularJS we have the `orderBy` pipe. But Angular seems to intentionally not have it.

There used to be an explanation of why the Angular team thought it was a bad idea to have such pipe [here](https://angular.io/guide/pipes#appendix-no-filterpipe-or-orderbypipe). But as you can see, the info is now missing from this page.

I've seen already other feature requests related to this: #2956 and #11337 and the summary of why the pipe should not be added seems based on:

> Angular 2 is unlikely to offer such pipes because (a) they perform poorly and (b) they prevent aggressive minification

But, correct me if I'm wrong:
* With pure pipes we don't need to worry in this case about (a) because as long as the input doesn't change, the pipe won't be executed.
* Nor worry about (b) because the implementation doesn't necessarily need to interfere with minification, as minification doesn't change the strings 'name' nor 'dob' that we pass in the template like `people | sortBy:['name', 'dob']` nor with the content of the list `people`. I've read that "sortBy relies on reflection" but that's not necessarily true, right?

The solution I've seen from the Angular team in those old issues is "do your own" but then, how come doing my own doesn't interfere with minification? and why is performance less of a concern there?

The main reason I'm requesting this is that when your users are upgrading from AngularJs to Angular they already need to do a fair amount of work. Not providing a 1:1 migration path in things like this, and asking every team to either write their own version of the pipe or trust one found in the Internet seems prone to bugs, raises security concerns and requires us to spend even more time.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I see these possible solutions:
- **Adding the pipe to Angular** but I've seen this has been answered multiple times with "no" so not putting my money on this one.
- **Adding the pipe to Angular as a separate npm package** just like you did with [material-moment-adapter](https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular/material-moment-adapter).
- **Providing a function to sortBy** that we can use in our controllers and that mimics AngularJs' one.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
* Using lodash, but although it allows sorting by multiple fields, it doesn't allow specifying the asc/desc order.
* Copying somebody's implementation to our company's codebase (but then I'm not making Angular better, next time there will be another frustrated user that needs to invest time into figuring out why Angular doesn't have this AngularJs pipe).

### Lastly
In case you consider any of those solutions is a "go", I can provide the PR.

Issues.Title: Clarify documentation around svg fragments in templates
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report

### Description

The Angular guide contains a section on how to use svg elements in templates, but this only deals with "complete" elements which include the base <svg> tag.

It is also useful to define components which render svg fragments within an existing parent svg element, which is not covered in the current docs. These only appear to work if the elements are prefixed with an (undefined?) "svg" namespace prefix.

Please update the docs to:
* Clarify if this is working as intended, or is just a by-product of the implementation which just happens to work.
* Include a similar example.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### Full Example
https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-5schxp

### What's the affected URL?
https://angular.io/guide/svg-in-templates

### Reproduction Steps

```ts
// app.component.ts
interface SvgRect {
  x: number;
  y: number;
  text: string;
}
export class AppComponent  {
  rects: SvgRect[];
}
```
```html
<!-- app.component.html -->
<!-- create a separate g for each rect -->
<svg width="200" height="100">
  <g svgRect *ngFor='let rect of rects' [rect]="rect"></g>
</svg>
```
```ts
// svg-rect.component.ts
@Component({
  selector: '[svgRect]',
  template: `
      <rect
          [attr.x]="rect.x" [attr.y]="rect.y" width="80" height="30"
          stroke="black" stroke-width="1" fill="transparent"></rect>
      <text
          [attr.x]="rect.x + 40" [attr.y]="rect.y + 15"
          dominant-baseline="middle" text-anchor="middle">{{rect.text}}</text>
  `,
  styles: []
})
export class SvgRectComponent  {
  @Input() rect: SvgRect;
}
```
This template as written does not render anything, although inspecting the underlying html looks ok. Following the advice in [this SO issue](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/48453514/angular-svg-matching-component-with-svg-elements), adding the "svg" namespace prefix to the component template elements does render correctly:
```ts
  template: `
      <svg:rect
          [attr.x]="rect.x" [attr.y]="rect.y" width="80" height="30"
          stroke="black" stroke-width="1" fill="transparent"></rect>
      <svg:text
          [attr.x]="rect.x + 40" [attr.y]="rect.y + 15"
          dominant-baseline="middle" text-anchor="middle">{{rect.text}}</text>
  `,
```
Would also be good to clarify whether the selector should include the svg namespace if restricted to a specific element:
```ts
  selector: 'g[svgRect]',
  selector: 'svn:g[svgRect]',
```
Thanks
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Clarify documentation around svg fragments in templates" (#40916)

Issues.Title: fix(forms): unsubscribe from async validator when the directive is destroyed
Issues.Body:
In the current behavior, the asynchronous validator is not unsubscribed,
thus creating a memory leak. For example, asynchronous validators can execute
HTTP requests, the HTTP request may still be in `pending` status when the directive
has already been destroyed. The `validate` method may capture `this` (e.g. if it references
the `HttpClient`) thus preventing the directive from being GC'd.

This RP adds a call to the `_cancelExistingSubscription` method when the directive is destroyed.

-   fix hashing order of runtime chunks when there are async entries involved

-   CI run tests on node.js 15 too
-   CI run tests on github actions too

### Experiments

-   improvements on experimental `output.library: { type: "module" }` (`experiments.outputModule: true`)
    -   it can generate `export { ... }` now, but that can't handle live-bindings yet

Issues.Title: For the compiler to detect missing template files within libraries.
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ Feature request

For the compiler to detect missing template files within libraries. Currently, on build of a library, if the template file is missing/invalid within a component, the error is vague and doesn't point back to the offending file or line. Instead, it just references the part of the compiler that has fallen over.

### Command

- [x] build (specifically `ng build {library-name}`)

### Description

When the build is executed in a project where the following invalid code exists:

```
@Component({
  selector: 'peanuts',
  templateUrl: './some-missing-file.component.html',
  styleUrls: ['./peanuts.scss'] // Error is helpful when changed to: "some-missing-file.scss"
})
```

The current error given in the CLI is this:

```
BUILD ERROR
Cannot read property 'length' of undefined
TypeError: Cannot read property 'length' of undefined
    at new _Tokenizer (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:10503:42)
    at tokenize (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:10462:16)
    at HtmlParser.Parser.parse (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:11093:35)
    at HtmlParser.parse (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:11428:43)
    at I18NHtmlParser.parse (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:17982:48)
    at DirectiveNormalizer._preparseLoadedTemplate (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:16276:55)
    at /my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:16270:80
    at Object.then (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:2491:81)
    at DirectiveNormalizer._preParseTemplate (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:16270:30)
    at DirectiveNormalizer.normalizeTemplate (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:16256:40)
    at CompileMetadataResolver.loadDirectiveMetadata (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:18448:62)
    at /my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:18629:41
    at Array.forEach (<anonymous>)
    at CompileMetadataResolver.loadNgModuleDirectiveAndPipeMetadata (/my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:18628:45)
    at /my-project/node_modules/@angular/compiler/bundles/compiler.umd.js:23827:69
    at Array.forEach (<anonymous>)
```

There is no reference to what caused the compiler to fall over.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Something more in line with the `styleUrls` 'not found or unreadable' error would be better:

```
BUILD ERROR
File to read not found or unreadable: /my-project/projects/my-library/src/lib/components/peanuts/some-missing-file.scss
```

or like in a standard project:

```
ERROR in ./src/app/cashews/cashews.component.ts
Module not found: Error: Can't resolve './some-invalid-file.html' in '/my-other-project/src/app/cashews'
```

##### Features

-   generate shorter output code for JSON data by using a `'...'` string instead of `"..."` (only affects output side when not minimized)
-   the `dependencies` configuration option now works for watch builds too
    -   It will build compilation when any of `dependencies` has changed

    -   relative request is missing leading `./`

-   add hint to stats how to get details about errors/warnings in child compilations

-   refactor libraries to inline exporting code into runtime to allow using with `output.iife: false`

-   avoid unnecessary calls to loaders when serializer are already registered
-   fix inner graph analysis for exports when `export { x }` is before pure declaration `const x = /*#__PURE__*/ f()`

Issues.Title: fix(testing): defineReadonlyEventProperty only if its not yet on the ‚Ä¶
Issues.Body:
We have a project that uses CDK for testing Angular components. Some components are wrappers around a third-party library. We have a case where we need to pass down an event to a third-party component and are out of control how many times `preventDefault` is called. Currently, our test suite fails due to the CDK if `preventDefault` is called multiple times.

On each `preventDefault` call the CDK tries to redefine the read-only Event Property `defaultPrevented`. In think that we should not fail on multiple `preventDefault` calls. From my point of view, it's not ideal to call `preventDefault` multiple times but also doesn't hurt.

This fix only tries to redefine `defaultPrevented` if it doesn't exist on the event.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(testing): defineReadonlyEventProperty only if its not yet on the ‚Ä¶" (#21944)
